question_text:

question_text:
Suppose f(x) is defined as follows:
‚ÄÉ‚ÄÉf(x) = { a + bx, for x < 1; 4, for x = 1; b - ax, for x > 1 }.
If lim‚Çì‚Üí1 f(x) = f(1), what are the values of a and b?
explanation:
For continuity at x = 1, the left-hand and right-hand limits must equal 4.
Left-hand limit (x ‚Üí 1‚Åª): a + b(1) = a + b.
Right-hand limit (x ‚Üí 1‚Å∫): b - a(1) = b - a.
Setting both equal to 4:
‚ÄÉa + b = 4‚ÄÉ‚ÄÉ(1)
‚ÄÉb - a = 4‚ÄÉ‚ÄÉ(2)
Adding (1) and (2): (a + b) + (b - a) = 2b = 8, so b = 4.
Substitute b = 4 into (1): a + 4 = 4, hence a = 0.

question_text:
Let f(x) be defined as follows:
‚ÄÉ‚ÄÉf(x) = { ‚Äñx‚Äñ + 1, for x < 0; 0, for x = 0; ‚Äñx‚Äñ - 1, for x > 0 }.

question_text:
If f(x) is defined piecewise as follows:
‚ÄÉ‚ÄÉf(x) = { m¬∑x¬≤ + n, for x < 0; m¬∑x + m, for 0 ‚â§ x ‚â§ 1; m¬∑x¬≥ + m, for x > 1 }.
For what integers m and n do both lim‚Çì‚Üí0 f(x) and lim‚Çì‚Üí1 f(x) exist?
correct_answer: m and n must satisfy n = m (with m being any integer)
explanation:
For continuity at x = 0, the left-hand and right-hand limits must match:
‚Ä¢ For x < 0, f(x) = m¬∑x¬≤ + n, so lim‚Çì‚Üí0‚Åª f(x) = n.
‚Ä¢ For 0 ‚â§ x ‚â§ 1, f(x) = m¬∑x + m, so lim‚Çì‚Üí0‚Å∫ f(x) = m.
Equate these to get n = m.
At x = 1, check both sides:
‚Ä¢ For x ‚Üí 1‚Åª, f(1) = m¬∑1 + m = 2m.
‚Ä¢ For x > 1, f(x) = m¬∑x¬≥ + m, so lim‚Çì‚Üí1‚Å∫ f(x) = m + m = 2m.
Thus, continuity (and hence the existence of the limit) at x = 1 is automatically satisfied when n = m. Therefore, for any integer m (with n = m), both limits exist.
